loans.name: Elmir

texts.en:
Elmir is an IDP from occupied Djebrail district of Azerbaijan. (IDP stands for Internally Displaced Person: Someone who has had to leave their home, but has not crossed an international border)

He fled to Baku in 1993, and started his business in 2000.

When he started his business, he borrowed two Normicro loans from the Baku branch totaling $1,000. Now he would like to borrow $1,000 for new equipment.

loans.use: To buy some new equipment for his shop

Anar is a vulnerable person from the Ujar-district of Azerbaijan. He came to Baku in 1996.

He is married and has two children.

He started his business in 1998 and borrowed four Normicro loans from the Baku branch totaling $1,400. Now he would like to borrow $1,000.

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Long V. is 35 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  V. watches over the children and also runs a mobile phone stand in her village. Her husband is an electrician and can usually make about $10 per day.  The couple hopes to use this loan to purchase second-hand televisions and radios that are not functioning properly. V.'s husband will then fix them and they will sell the appliances for a profit.  In the near future, they would like to open their own shop fixing electrical appliances. Later on, they hope to be able to buy a concrete house and to send their children to university.

loans.use: To purchase second-hand televisions and radios for business

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lender,

Great news! Long Vanary has repaid the Kiva loan early! Kiva and CREDIT MFI make every effort to be as transparent as possible so you can trust the information we give you. In this case, we didn’t let you know that the loan had been repaid at the time. Occasionally, when a loan is repaid early, the payment schedule posted on Kiva doesn’t always match the records of our micro finance partner in Cambodia, CREDIT MFI. As in life, the system doesn’t always run perfectly, but when there is a discrepancy we will alert you as soon as possible so you have all the information about your investment.

On the upside, the issue occurred because the client’s business is so successful! Your loan made that possible. Soon you will see a repayment posted on the client’s profile that is larger than the usual amount. This will end the loan and return the funds to your account. We hope you will choose to loan the repaid funds to another entrepreneur who would a like a chance to grow their business as well. 

If you have any questions, please post them as a comment on this borrowers site and I will be happy to respond. I also encourage you to write comments on the pages of your loan recipients so we can pass along your good wishes to the borrowers.

We sincerely apologize for the oversight and are putting policies in place to make sure that it doesn’t happen again. Thank you for giving poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia a chance at success! 

Best regards,

Sopheap Khiev, Kiva partnership coordinator, Cambodia
Mr. Chan Mach, General Manager, CREDIT MFI, Cambodia

loans.name: Luis

texts.en:
Luis S. is a farmer from a rural town named Salitre. There, he has a small farm where grows rice and corn. Luis has four children, two of which are all grown up and independent. The other two work with Luis on his farm while living in homes of their own. Luis will use the loan in order to purchase fertilizer and buy seeds. He wants to make the investment primarily in rice seeds now that the rainy season is coming to an end and the lands are fertile.

He is the latest addition to the first Communal Bank in the new Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Resistencia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Salitre named Resistencia. They will use the microloans to prepare the lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Resistencia Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many microfinance programs, but is imperative for the communities Mifex works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Loan Use and Repayment

The loans in this sector will be used to create water deposits that will prevent flooding in the case of heavy rains or store water in case of droughts. They will also be used to treat the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase fertilizer. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical microentrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

Below is more information about Salitre compiled by the staff at Mifex when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Salitre

Salitre is a rural sector in the Province of Guayas known as the capital of Montuvios (montuvio is a cowboy) with approximately 30,000 inhabitants. The main economic activities are herding and agriculture which make up about 80% of the economy. The infrastructure and basic services are poor, especially the roads and water services.

Salitre is highly dedicated to farming rice and cattle ranching. Rice is a crop that yields about every four months. In order to farm rice, the environment must be very humid and there must be a high volume of water. The lack of a structured water system makes it difficult for the small farmers to be highly productive. The best months for cultivating rice are early in the year when it is the rainy season in the coast of Ecuador.

Salitre is a national tourist attraction as many Ecuadorians visit the fresh water Salitre River. There are cottages, small restaurants and water attractions that people come to enjoy.

Access to Credit

There is not a single financial institution that provides services to the productive sector of the local economy. The only access to credit comes from loan sharks who charge extremely high interest rates averaging around 20% a month. The locals are also exploited by the intermediaries that buy their products in order to commercialize them in the city and to export abroad. These intermediaries buy crops in advance at very low prices, finance soil at extremely high prices and often provide emergency loans for even higher interest rates than the loan sharks.

Risks

Salitre is a dangerous sector considering it is in the rural area. There is a high incidence of robbery of cattle that results in many of the ranch owners owning weapons to protect their property. Because the police are not present in these areas, farmers and ranchers must apply their own laws and provide their own security. In some instances they have formed their own cooperatives and associations to have a community crime prevention effort.

Salitre is in the lowlands of Ecuador and is vulnerable to flooding in the rainy season. In the event of a heavy rainy season, often at its worse when El Niño occurs, the farmers of rice lose many of their crops. All this is due to a lack of infrastructure in the area.

loans.use: Purchase rice seeds and fertilizer

payments.comment: 1er pago de asociaciòn resistencia de salitre

loans.name: Tomas

texts.en:
Tomas S. is a farmer from a rural town outside of the big city of Guayaquil named Salitre. Tomas and his wife Hortencia have lived on these lands for over 30 years. There they have raised three children who are all on their own now. Tomas is seeking to receive a loan so that hey may invest in rice farming. The rainy season is just coming to an end and this is a particularly good time to plant the rice seeds and prepare the lands. The loan will help Tomas avoid borrowing from the loan sharks common to the area. Although he knows they charge exuberant interest rates, Tomas has been forced to borrow from these lenders several times due to his shortage of capital.

He is the latest addition to the first Communal Bank in the new Mifex Rural Finance Program. loans.name: Belkis

texts.en:
Belkis S. D. L. C. lives with her husband Victor. She owns her own beauty parlor and boutique. She started with a small loan of just $60. Belkis S. has taken various loans since then and is now requesting this loan to restock and expand her current product line. She has successfully paid off her previous loans and has demonstrated that her business can benefit from a larger loan. She says her goal is to continue growing her business.

NOTE: Belkin is a member of a Bank of Hope solidarity group consisting of five microentrepreneurs. They have gone through Esperanza's training program and have created their own businesses. They will receive their share of this $750 loan to expand their respective businesses and will be responsible for making each payment together. They are accountable to one another for paying in full and on time.

loans.use: Purchase hair care products and salon equipment

loans.name: Janbulat

texts.en:
Janbulat is a local resident of Beylagan, a town of Azerbaijan. He is 38 years old and married with three children.

Since 2001, he has been engaged in vehicle spare parts sales. He has his own small shop. He sells spare parts of different types and for different vehicles.

When he opened his shop, he had little of his own capital to buy enough inventory, and he applied to Normicro's Beylagan branch for a loan and borrowed $400. Later he borrowed two more loans.

Thanks to these loans, he established better sales and has permanent customers. But he is not satisfied with the volume of sales and wants to increase the stock of inventory, thus increasing the volume of sales.

He needs a $1,200 loan now for this purpose.

loans.use: To buy new goods for his stock

loans.name: Zamig

texts.en:
Zamig is a local resident of Beylagan town. He is 25 years old and not married.

He has been involved in spare parts sales since 2002. He has built a small shop for himself and sells spare parts for different types of vehicles.

He buys spare parts from the city of Baku or has them brought from Russia. He has permanent customers as he sells goods of high quality.

He has run this business for five years, but the volume of sales is not satisfactory for him yet. He wants more inventory in his shop and more sales.

He applied to Normicro's Beylagan branch this year for a loan. He needs $800 for the first-time loan.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Gertrudis

texts.en:
Gertrudis H. and her husband Juan Fulgencio live with their four children in San Pedro de Macorís. Gertrudis used her first loan of $300 to start her own clothing store, and she used her profits to send her sons to private school. Gertrudis has paid off her first loan and has developed a business plan to expand her inventory to include cosmetics. This new loan will give her the capital to purchase cosmetics and personal care products.

A high-quality education is something she and her husband value greatly, and they are focused on giving their children the opportunity to attend schools that offer much more than the public schools do. Her goal is to increase her profits so that she can send her oldest son to college soon, as well as her younger children once they finish secondary school.

loans.use: Start a business selling cosmetics and personal care products

loans.name: Balay

texts.en:
Balay is an IDP from the Armenian-occupied Fizuli region of Azerbaijan. (IDP stands for Internally Displaced Person: Someone who has had to leave their home, but has not crossed an international border)

He is 50 years old, married and has four children. In his home district, he was working as a truck driver in a mobile mechanized construction unit.

Later he privatized the truck and started to provide transportation services. He transports agricultural goods to markets in Baku in the summertime, and also transports construction materials and other goods.

The old truck requires permanent maintenance, which is his biggest expense.

He has borrowed two loans from Normicro Beylagan branch, with the first in 2005 amounting to $300 and another for $700 in 2006. He had the motor of the truck reassembled thanks to these loans.

Now he needs $900 to buy eight new tires to keep the truck in good shape for this summer.

loans.use: To buy eight new tires

loans.name: Gizbes

texts.en:
Gizbes is a 47-year-old resident of Beylagan town. She rents a small place in the local market where she sells women's clothing.

She has been involved in this business since 2000. This is the only income for her family, which includes her husband and three children. Her husband is not working at the moment.

Her stock of goods is short now, and she does not have her own funds. She didn't want to lose her clients and decided to apply for a loan from Normicro's Beylagan branch.

She wants $700 for a first-time loan to increase the stock of goods.

loans.use: To increase the variety of goods

loans.name: Tahir

texts.en:
Tahir is a local resident of Beylagan town. He has his own barber shop.

At first, he was renting the shop. He bought it in 2002. He is 24 years old and single.

He has wanted to renovate the interior of the shop since he bought it, but he has had no funds to do it.

He wants to buy new furniture and a chair, and also a pair of hair-cutting machines. This way he will be able to attract more clients and increase his income.

He has applied to Normicro's Beylagan branch for a loan. He needs $700 for the first-time loan.

loans.use: To buy new inventory

loans.name: Catalina Beltres

texts.en: Catalina Beltres E., age 71, has been a member of Esperanza's program for almost ten years. Her first business was a fruit stand, which she started with a loan of $90. In September 1998, hurricane George caused massive devastation to the Dominican Republic and surrounding Caribbean countries. Catalina lost her husband and her business. After several loans, Catalina demonstrated her resiliance and has since started a new clothing business. This loan of $450 will allow Catalina to increase  her inventory and branch out into new styles. Her goal is to continue expanding her business.

loans.use: Purchase new clothing to expand her inventory

loans.name: Serafín

texts.en: Serafín G. and her husband Alfida Betres have four children. Serafín helps support her family by running her furniture manufacturing business. She makes tables, chairs, and various other pieces from scratch, then sells them wholesale to retail stores and distribudors around the province of San Pedro de Macorís. She is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase more wood and tools to take her business to the next level. She has received and repaid several loans of increasingly larger amounts from Esperanza, proving that her business has the potential to keep growing.

loans.use: Purchase wood and tools for shaping, building, sanding, and polishing furniture

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro J. has 2 children, whom he raises wih his wife Dania Rosario. Pedro sells baseball caps in an outdoor street market in the city. His goal is to keep expanding his business. This loan will allow Pedro to purchase more hats and clothing to meet the growing demand for his products in the market. The many fans of the local baseball team, the Estrellas Orientales, as well as fans of baseball in general, represent a large niche market, but Pedro plans to expand his client base by offering clothing as well.

NOTE: Pedro is a member of an Esperanza solidarity group consisting of 5 microentrepreneurs. The group has gone through Esperanza's training program, developed a business plan, and will be responsible for repaying their share of this $750 loan together. They are accountable to one another for making full, timely payments. If someone is short or late on a payment, the other group members must make up the difference.

loans.use: Purchase clothing to expand inventory

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana se inicio en el comercio vendiendo arroz por quintales por falta de capital dejo ese negocio y con algo de ahorro se puso una tienda en su casa la misma que la tiene desde hace 2 años. Juana atiende a sus clientes todos los días de la semana desde las 6: AM a 22: PM El esposo de Juana la apoya su negocio

Juana solicita el préstamo para compra de víveres de primera necesidad: arroz, azúcar, aceite, carnes, pollos y otros. Así de esta manera surte su negocio y cumple con las necesidades de sus clientes.

Juana tiene 47 años 2 hijos y a su cargo 1 el mismo que estudia. El esposo de Juana la apoya en la atención del negocio y trabaja como maestro constructor.

English:

Translated by Nuria Ruiz, Kiva Voluteer.

Juana started her business selling rice in big amounts. Due to lack of capital she had to leave that business and she started her little store. She and her husband work there every day from 6am to 10pm.

Juana is requesting a loan to buy goods for her business. She 's planning on using the money to buy rice, sugar, oil, meat, chicken and others. That way she can have a better stocked store and thus , better serve her clients.

Juana is 47 years old and she has two sons. Her husband is very supportive of her enterprises; besides helping her in the store, he works in construction.

loans.use: Invertir en viveres como carne, pollo, aceite y azucar

loans.name: Octavia

texts.en:
Octavia D. L. C. is a single mother with two children. She is requesting her first loan to start a business manufacturing bedspreads. She already has a sewing machine, and she will use this loan to purchase materials and supplies to get her business underway. She says her goal is to develop her business for personal growth and to give her children a good education.

NOTE: Octavia is a member of the Jehová Suple solidarity group along with four other microentrepreneurs in her community. They have gone through Esperanza's training program and developed a business plan with the guidance of their loan advisor, Cristina Moreno. They will be responsible for repaying their share of this loan and covering for one another should a member be late or short on a payment. This group-lending methodolgy is a proven way to increase social support and accountability among group members.

loans.use: Purchase textile materials and supplies for making bedsheets and quilts

loans.name: Eulegio

texts.en:
Eulegio H. is a rice farmer in the rural Ecuadorian coastal county of Baba. He has had his land for 40 years, which is where he lives with his wife, Mariana. He has a very basic level of education, given the economic situation of his parents, which meant that they couldn’t send him to high school. He is a very hardworking man who is dedicated to making his land successful. He hopes to receive the loan to be able to invest it in rice seed and fertilizer, which he uses to make the rice grow faster.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Eulegio H. es un arrocero del sector rural en la costa ecuatoriana llamado Baba. El tiene sus tierras hace unos 40 anos donde el a vivido con su esposa Mariana. El tiene un nivel muy basico de educación dado a la situación economica de sus padres que no lo pudieron mandar al colegio. El es un hombre muy trabajador dedicado al éxito de sus tierras. El espera recibir el préstamo para poder invertir en semillas de arroz y el fertilizante que se usa para que crezca más rápido.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Rosa de Oro (Golden Rose) Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Rosa de Oro helps the farmers by providing access to machinery, training services and government assistance. The farmers from Rosa de Oro are very close to each other and cooperate to help one another on their farms.

The members of Rosa de Oro will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Rosa de Oro Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Baba compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large mulitnational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Baba

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: To cultivate rice

payments.comment: 1er pago de asociación Rosa de oro

Este crédito del Eulogio procedió a cancelarlo con la cosecha del arroz , siendo uno de los deudores que a procedido a realizar su pago total, quedando algunos agricultores pendientes de pago por cuanto les falta cosechar o vender sus productos

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio is from the county of Baba, a rice-growing region on the Ecuadorian coast. Antonio has lived in Baba since he was born there 70 years ago. He has a rice farm where he, his wife, Paula, and several of their children work together to harvest the product. He is very happy that he is still a leader in his family and that he can help them earn a living. He wants to invest in fertilizer and pesticides for the rice, products which will make his lands more productive.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Antonio es del canton Baba, un sector arrocero en la costa ecuatoriana. Antonio ha vivido en Baba desde que nacio hace 70 años. El tiene arroz en su finca donde el, su esposa Paula y varios de sus hijos trabajan en conjunto para cosechar el producto. El esta bien feliz que todavía es un lider en su familia y les puede ayudar sobrevivir. El quiere invertir en fertilizante y pesticidas para el arroz, productos que le harán mas productivas sus tierras y para que tenga mas rendimiento.

Communal Banking in Baba

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. loans.use: To invest in rice

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The loan will be used to pay suppliers and buy products for the store (notebooks, pens and pencils, general paper goods, etc.).

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The loan will be used to buy supplies for the convenience store (milks, eggs, bread, drinks, rice, beans, etc.).

loans.name: San Juana

texts.en:
Mrs. San Juana has had her business for 8 months. “I had to work very hard in order to have my own business. Now what I need is more merchandise because the customers are always requesting many things. Also, I would like to paint the exterior of my business, because the walls are very scratched. I am requesting $1,000.00 to invest in my business.”

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. San Juana tiene 8 meses con su negocio “Tuve que trabajar mucho para poder tener mi negocio propio ahora lo que me hace falta es más mercancía ya que la gente me pide muchas cosas, también quisiera pintar por fuera mi negocio ya que las paredes estan muy rayadas”. Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para invertir en mi negocio.

loans.use: To invest in buying merchandise for my business.

loans.name: Alma Delia

texts.en:
Alma has had her business for more than one year. “My business is the sale of new clothing. I would like to buy clothes for the Spring—Summer season, but I don’t have the money to invest in the inventory. I am requesting $1,200.00 to invest in my business.”

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Alma tiene su negocio desde hace 1 año “Mi negocio es de venta de ropa nueva me gustaría comprar ropa de temporada Primavera-Verano pero no cuento con el dinero para hacer la inversión”. Solicito $ 1,200.00 dlls para invertir en mi negocio.

loans.use: To invest in inventory of clothing for my business.

loans.name: Rosa Linda

texts.en:
Rosa Linda has had a business selling decorations for a year and a half. “My business is located on the street, where there is a lot of competition. For this reason, I would like to have more merchandise and I would also like to buy a vitrine to display some small items I have for sale. I am requesting $1,000.00 to invest in my business.”

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Rosa Linda tiene un negocio de venta de curiosidades desde hace 1 año y medio “Mi negocio esta en una calle en donde hay mucha competencia así es que me gustaría tener más mercancía y comprar también una vitrina para acomodar algunos objetos pequeños que tengo en venta”.Solicito 1,000.00 dlls para invertir en mi negocio.

loans.use: To invest in my business.

loans.name: Rosa Martha

texts.en:
Rosa Martha has had a business selling used clothing for 6 months. “I have very little clothing for sale in my business due to the fact that I don’t have money to invest in inventory. I would like to buy more merchandise because the warm season is coming. I am requesting $1000.00 to invest in my business.”

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Rosa Martha tiene una venta de segunda desde hace 6 meses “Tengo muy poca ropa en mi negocio debído a que no cuento con dinero para la inversión y me gustaría comprar más mercancía ya que se aproxima la temporada de calor”. Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para invertí en mi negocio.

loans.use: To invest in merchandise for my business.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes has had her business for one and a half years. “My business is the sale of second-hand items. I have all sorts of accessories for the home and I would like to buy more inventory so that my sales can increase. I am requesting $1,000.00 to invest in merchandise for my business.”

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Lourdes tiene 1 año y medio con su negocio. “Mi negocio es de venta de segunda tengo accesorios de todo tipo para el hogar y me gustaría comprar más cosas para que mis ventas aumenten”. Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para invertir en mercancía para mi negocio.

loans.use: To invest in my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy products for the hardware store and pay suppliers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The loan will be used to enlarge the pharmacy and buy medicines to supply it.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The loan will be used to purchase beauty products and new clothes to stock her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The loan will be used on air conditioning for the store and to purchase products to stock it.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The loan will be used to enlarge the hair salon and purchase the equipment needed to better serve customers (hair dryer, electric shaver, clippers, combs, etc.).

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The loan will be invested in enlarging and improving the eatery, along with the purchase of a new stove.

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro nacio y ha vivido en el sector arrocero de Baba toda su vida. Desde que nacio el y su familia han subsistido gracias al arroz. El ahora tiene una finca desde hace 30 años donde el tiene varias cuadras de arroz. El quiere invertir en trabajadores que le ayuden a sembrar, ya que no quiere usar la ayuda de hijo para que pueda seguir estudiando. El tiene dos hijos, uno de 11 y el otro de 28 años.

English Translation:

Translated by Nuria Ruiz, Kiva Voluteer.

Pedro was born and raise in Baba. Since his family can remember their worked in the rice fields. Since 30 years ago Pedro has a plot of land where he cultivates rice. He is requesting a loan to hire some laborers that would help him seed. He has a son but he prefers he continues his studies rather than work on the fields. His oldest is 28 years old and the youngest is 11.

Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Sembrar arroz

loans.name: José Raymundo

texts.en:
Jose Raymundo is a married man and works in marble and granite. He has three children who all go to school, they are 12, 17 and 18. His wife works as an operator at a factory and he began his business because he needed a higher income in order to cover family expenses and the education of his three children. He has worked in his business for 2 years now and has had success, as his work is good and his first clients began to recommend him to friends and this has allowed his business to grow a little.

Jose is asking for a loan of $475 in order to buy materials and to finish his work for clients and to have sufficient inventory for future jobs. He proposes to repay the loan in 6-12 months. He hopes your help will allow him to finish his projects and to improve his family's quality of life, and he thanks you in advance.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

José Raymundo es un hombre casado que se dedica a hacer trabajos en mármol y en granito. Tiene tres hijos los cuales se encuentran estudiando de 12, 17 y 18 años. Su esposa trabaja como operaria en una empresa y él inició su negocio por la necesidad de un mejor ingreso para poder sustentar el gasto de la familia y la educación de sus tres hijos, tiene dos años con el negocio y le ha ido bien por que sus trabajos son buenos y sus primeros clientes comenzaron a recomendarlo entre sus conocidos y esto le ha permitido ir creciendo poco a poco.

José esta solicitando un préstamo por US $ 475 para utilizarlo en la compra de materiales para terminar los trabajos que tiene solicitados y así cumplir con sus clientes, mantener su demanda y estar con suficiente inventario para los trabajos futuros, ofrece pagar este préstamo en un lapso de 6 a 12 meses; espera de tu apoyo para poder cumplir con sus trabajos y sacar adelante a su familia y te agradecen por anticipado.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is married and has four children, her husband is retired and also helps her in the store. She began her business because she needed to be able to support her family. As she does not have her own home, she has to pay rent where she lives, which only adds to her financial responsibilities. She needed to earn a little more money than they received from her husband's income, and so with a little bit of savings she was able to purchase many items which she then resold, reinvesting the money earned in more merchandise and thus allowing her business to grow little by little. Now she has been running her business for five years and is very hard-working, she tends her store from Monday to Sunday from 7am-10pm.

Gloria is asking for a loan of $700 in order to purchase merchandise for her business and to have a wider variety in stock to offer to customers and to continue with her business' growth. She proposes to repay the loan in 6-12 months and awaits your help so that she can improve her life along with her family's, who all thank you.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Gloria esta casada y tiene cuatro hijos, su esposo es jubilado y la ayuda en el negocio. Inició su negocio por la necesidad de aportar en la economía familiar. Como ella no tiene casa propia tiene que pagar renta en el lugar donde vive, eso más los gastos familiares la obligaron a ver que podía hacer para obtener un ingreso extra al de su esposo y ayudarlo, así con un pequeño ahorro compro muy pocas cosas y se puso a vender, reinvirtiendo lo poco que le quedaba en más mercancía y fue creciendo poco a poco, ya tiene más de cinco años con el negocio y es muy trabajadora, ella atiende en su negocio de lunes a domingo desde las 7:00am hasta las 10:00pm.

Gloria esta solicitando un préstamo de US $ 700 para comprar mercancía para su negocio y así tener un mayor surtido de productos que ofrecer a sus clientes y continuar creciendo para poder tener un mejor futuro, ofrece pagar este préstamo en un período de 6 a 12 meses y espera de tu apoyo para que pueda salir adelante junto con su familia, ellos te lo agradecen.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Manuela

texts.en:
Manuela is a widow and has four married children, though she lives with her grandson who is 15, and who she also takes care of. She began her business when her husband died, though she already had a job as a secretary, after her husband's death she could not earn enough income to support her family's needs as well as her children's educational expenses. And so she opened a tailoring store, a skill which she already knew how to do, and with time bought a small sewing machine to help her make vests for Kindergarteners and so her business began to grow.

Manuela is asking for a loan of $925 to buy a sewing machine that will allow her to give a better service to a larger quantity of customers and thus continue to allow her business to grow. She is very hard-working and offers to repay the loan in 6-12 months, she awaits your support in her project and thanks you for your help.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor

Manuela es una mujer viuda y tiene 4 hijos casados, ella vive con su nieto de 15 años al cual mantiene. Empezó con su negocio al fallecer su esposo, ya que ella trabajaba como secretaria y al fallecer su esposo con su ingreso no podía mantener los gastos familiares que eran altos por que no solo era los gastos de la casa sino la educación de sus hijos, en ese momento empezó con la costura que era lo que sabía hacer, con el tiempo compro una maquinita que la ayudo a hacer chalecos para Kinder y comenzó a crecer con su negocio.

Manuela esta requiriendo un préstamo de US $ 925 para comprar una maquina que le permita dar más servicio a una mayor cantidad de clientes y continuar con su crecimiento, ella es una mujer muy trabajadora y ofrece pagar el préstamo en un período de 6 a 12 meses, espera que la apoyen con su proyecto y agradece de tu apoyo.

loans.use: To purchase tools and supplies

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson es nativo del sector arrocero de Baba. El vive con sus tres hijos y dos hijos de un compromiso de su esposa que tenia antes. Wilson ha podido mantener su familia gracias a la producción de arroz y plátano que le da su hacienda. El quiere invertir en fertilizantes y pesticidas para mantener y cosechar estos productos. El tiene la esperanza de arreglar su casita que ahora es de caña y esta vulnerable a las lluvias.

English:

Translated by Nuria Ruiz, Kiva Voluteer.

Wilson family has lived in Baba for a long time. His family has always worked in the rice fields and industry in Baba. He lives with his wife and five children, two of his children are from his prior partner. Wilson is been able to provide for his family thanks to the rice and banana production of his plot of land. He is requesting a loan to buy pesticides and fertilizers for his crops and to fix his house. Right now his house is made out of bamboo and thus not very well suited for rainy season.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Rosa de Oro (Golden Rose) Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Rosa de Oro helps the farmers by providing access to machinery, training services and government assistance. The farmers from Rosa de Oro are very close to each other and cooperate to help one another on their farms.

The members of Rosa de Oro will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Rosa de Oro Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Baba compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large mulitnational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Baba

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Cosechar arroz

loans.name: Emilio

texts.en:
Emilio ha vivido en Baba por 35 años cultivando arroz. En sus tierras también tiene otros productos como el plátano y el maíz, pero el que es su negocio es el arroz. El tiene 4 hijos que ya son adultos y que lo apoyan a su padre en su actividad de agricultura. El y su esposa viven solos en su casa que es de madera y cementa. El quiere seguir haciendo arreglos en su hogar después de hacer su inversión en la agricultura.

English:

Translated by Nuria Ruiz, Kiva Voluteer.

Emilio has grown rice in Baba for 35 years. In his land he also has other crops like bananas and corn but his main sustenance comes from rice. He has four grown up children that help him with the land. He and his wife live by themselves on their house, made out of wood an cement. He is requesting a loan for agricultural purposes but also to remodel his house that needs some fixing.

loans.use: Sembrar Arroz

loans.name: Agopito

texts.en:
Agapito es un señor de mayor edad pero que sigue trabajando en sus tierras dado a las necesidades de la vida. A pesar de su edad, el pueda todavía salir al campo y sembrar el arroz, actividad que le ha dado de comer por toda su vida. El tiene una casa humilde de madera donde el vive con su esposa y unos de sus hijos. El quiere el préstamo para poder solicitar la ayuda de unos trabajadores que lo ayuden en su actividad.

English:

Translated by Nuria Ruiz, Kiva Voluteer.

Agapito is an old man. He, however, still works the land since he needs to provide for his family. Despite of not being young he still can go out to the fields and seed rice. He lives in a humble home with his wife and some of his children. Agapito is requesting a loan to hire some workers that help him cultivate the land.

loans.use: Siembra de arroz

payments.comment: 1 er pago asociación Rosa de Oro

loans.name: Leonidas

texts.en:
Leonidas es un campesino de Baba, un sector de Ecuador donde predomina la producción del arroz. El esta solicitando un prestamo para poder invertir en los productos necesarios para sembrar, como las semillas y el fertilizante. El tiene 6 hijos, uno de los cuales todavía lo esta apoyando en sus estudios. El resto también son arroceros, e inclusivo hay varios que lo ayudan a el en sus tierras. Leonida espera mejorar su vivienda con el prestamo, ya que ahora es de madera y es bien vulnerable a las lluvias fuertes que frecuentan el sector.

English:

Translated by Nuria Ruiz, Kiva Voluteer.

Leonidas is a peasant from Baba, a region of Ecuador where the main source of income is the cultivation of rice. He is requesting a loan to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Leonidas has six children , one of which is still studing. The rest of his kids are also rice laborers, some of them help him with the land. Leaonidas plans to also use some of the loan money to do some improvements on his house. His home is made of wood and thus not fitted for the rainy season.

Communal Banking in Baba

loans.use: Invertir en arroz en su finca

payments.comment: 1er pago de asociación Rosa de Oro

loans.name: Yous

texts.en: Yous C. is 45 years old living with her husband and 3 children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She makes her living by selling fruits near the factory and can usually make around $3 a day. C.'s husband works as a moto-taxi driver and makes about $5 per day. One of the couple's daughters is a garment worker and contributes all her salary to the household. C. hopes to use the loan to purchase a moto-cycle for her husband to run his business and to generate additional income. In the future, the couple expect to purchase a stand at the local market to sell a variety of fruits and hope to sponsor their children's studies until they get a job themselves.

loans.use: To buy moto-taxi to generate additional income.

loans.name: Shukufa

texts.en:
Shukufa G. lives in the Beylagan region. She is 50 years old. Her husband died a few years ago, and she has two children.

She is engaged in sheep-breeding.

In 2007, she applied to Normicro's Beylagan branch for a loan in the amount of $400. She used this loan to buying 10 sheep.

She wants to purchase more animals.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Seyyara

texts.en:
Seyyara is an IDP from the occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. (Internally Displaced Person: Someone who has had to leave their home, but has not crossed an international border.) She fled to Baku in 1993.

She is married and has three children. She and her husband, who is in the picture, started her business in 2003. They borrowed a $500 loan from Normicro's Baku branch. Now she would like to borrow $1,000.

loans.use: To renovate equipment

loans.name: Charkaz

texts.en: Charkaz is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied Jabrail district of Azerbaijan.  His wife is pictured in photo. He fled to Baku in 1993. He is married and has two children. He started his family business of cattle breeding in 2000. He has no funds to develop his business and now would like to borrow $1,000 from Normicro Baku branch.

loans.use: To expand the volume of business

loans.name: Dostu

texts.en:
Dostu B. lives in the Alinazarli village of the Beylagan region. He is 48 years old. Dostu is married, and he has two children.

He is engaged in cattle-breeding. This year, he borrowed a loan from Normicro's Beylagan branch in the amount of $400 and bought one cow. He is developing his job, and cattle-breeding is improving day by day.

loans.use: For buying one cow

loans.name: Sona

texts.en: Sona is an IDP (internally displaced person) from the occupied Fizuli district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. She and her husband (in the photo) have two children. They started the family business in 1995. Sona is planning to use the loan to increase the assortment of food in the business.

loans.use: To increase product inventory

loans.name: Shakar

texts.en: Shakar G. lives in Beylagan, where she has a small booth in the village of Ashigli. She established her business 5 years ago. In 2007, she received a loan from Normicro, Beylagan Branch, and was able to buy more products for her booth. Now her business is doing very well.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Mobil

texts.en: Mobil M. lives in the Beylagan region. He is 42 years old, and is married, with four children. Mobil has his own tire-repair service. He applied for credit to the Normicro Beylagan Branch in 2007 and was able to buy some equipment for his repair service.

loans.use: To buy equipment

loans.name: Samaya

texts.en: Samaya is a refugee from Armenia who fled to Baku in 1989. She is married and has three children. In 2000, she borrowed $500 loan from Normicro Baku branch and started her business in 2000. Now her husband would like to borrow $1000 to expand the business.

loans.use: To expand business volume

loans.name: Maya

texts.en: Maya is an IDP (internally displaced person) from the occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. She and her husband (in the photo) fled to Baku in 1993. They have five children. She started her business in 2000, and borrowed three Normicro loans from the Baku branch totaling $7000. Now she would like to borrow $1000 to expand the business.

loans.use: To increase volume of business

loans.name: Arzu

texts.en: Arzu fled to Baku in 1993 from the occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. She is married with two children. She and her husband (in the photo) started their business in 2000, and borrowed two Normicro loans from the Baku branch totaling $900. Now they would like to borrow $1000 to expand the store inventory.

loans.use: To increase the variety of goods in the store

loans.name: Mais

texts.en: Mais K. is from Badu, the capital city of Azerbaijan. He is married and has two children. He started his business in 1998 and would like to borrow $1100 to expand the inventory of goods in his store.

loans.use: To increase the variety of goods in his food store

loans.name: Vagif

texts.en: Vagif J. is from the Apsheron district of Azerbaijan. He is married, with two children. He started his business in 2003, and took a loan of $500. Now he would like to borrow $1000 to expand the store inventory.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Araz

texts.en: Araz A. left the occupied Jebrail district of Azerbaijan in 1993 and fled to Baku. Araz is married, with one child. He started an auto repair business in 2000, and needs a loan of $1000 to buy new equipment for the shop.

loans.use: To buy modern equipment for his auto repair business

loans.name: Nazile

texts.en: Nazile A. is from Baku, the capital city of Azerbaijan. She started her business in 2000 with two loans totaling $1000. With a new loan of $700, she will be able to increase the inventory of her shop.

loans.use: To increase the variety of goods

loans.name: Aida

texts.en: Aida A. fled to Baku from the occupied Agdam district of Azerbaijan in 1993. She is married, with two children. She started her sewing business in 1998 with two loans totaling $1000. She currently needs a new loan of $1000 in order to buy new equipment for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To buy modern equipment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Susan would like to purchase food supplies for her cafe as well as run a small hotel and buy furniture for it.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Lucy would like to buy a digital camera and digital video recorder for her photography business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jane would like to rent a stall and buy mores stock for her general wares shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jane would like to purchase an energy-saving oven, buy ingredients and hire assistants in order to expand her bakery.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Esther would like to purchase stocks of used clothes to expand her used clothes selling business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Pherisnah would like to expand her weaving and basketry business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Rahab would like to purchase food stocks for her grocery business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Mary would like to buy more used shoes in order to expand her used shoes business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Rose would like to buy more food stocks and supplies for her grocery shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To be able to buy more auto spare parts and employ two more mechanics for her garage business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more stocks of watches and general electronics, rent a room for his general electronics business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more stocks of general wares in order to expand his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fish stocks and refrigeration equipment needed to start her fish-selling business

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph M. M. is 24 years old and is married with one child. He is also the firstborn in his family and has to take care of his siblings six of who are all of school going age. His mother is a single and has no any other source of help other than his son. He owns a semi-permanent shop where he sells small electronic items (like pocket size radios), caps and bags. He intends to get a better shop and buy more stock to be able to earn more income .
He is requesting for a loan of US$800 to help him expand his business.US$300 to rent and furnish the shop,US$200 to pay for the local authority licenses.,US$300 to buy stock. Given this loan, he will be able to improve his business and thus earn more return to meet all his family needs  effectively

loans.use: To be able to buy general electronic accessories needed to expand his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more used handbag stocks needed to expand her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase New  uncut materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more stocks of fresh and dried fish for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more fish stocks and fish fillet stocks to be able to expand her business

loans.name: Ismael

texts.en:
Ismael has had his business for three months. “I have a cart on a tricycle from which I sell corn-on-the-cob outside a school, but I want to invest a little in buying more merchandise so that I can increase my income. I am requesting $1,000.00 to invest in my business.”

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. Ismael tiene su negocio desde hace 3 meses. “Tengo un triciclo en donde vendo elotes afuera de una escuela pero quiero invertirle un poco comprando más mercancía y poder vender más para que aumenten mis ingresos. Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para invertir en mi negocio”.

loans.use: To invest in my business.

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Sara has had her business for 1 year. “I have a small grocery store, but I need a lot more merchandise. I would like to buy more, but I don’t have the money to do it. It would be very helpful, in order to increase my income. My children and I live from the income from this business. I am requesting $1,000.00 to invest in my business.”

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Sara tiene su negocio desde hace 1 año. “Tengo una tienda de abarrotes pero me falta mucha mercancía me,gustaría poder comprar más pero no tengo dinero para hacerlo me ayudaría mucho para que aumenten mis ingresos ya que de aquí del negocio es de donde vivimos mis hijos y yo. Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para invertir en mi negocio”.

loans.use: To invest in my business.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Ángela has been working with her business for one year and a half. "I have my business in my home, so the space is very small and I would like to expand a little, now that everything has been set up well. That way I can buy more merchandise and have a place for to fit it in." I am requesting $1000.00 to expand my business.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

La Sra Ángela tiene 1 año y medio con su negocio “Mi negocio lo tengo en mi casa así es que el espacio es muy pequeño y me gustaría ampliarme un poco ya que tengo todo muy amontonado y así poder compras más mercancía y tener donde acomodarla”. Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para ampliar mi negocio.

loans.use: Expand my business

loans.name: Qui

texts.en: Mrs. Qui's husband died long ago. She must support 4 children. Huong, her first daughter, died of womb cancer last year. Mrs. Qui also had a malignant tumour in her breast and she lost much money to have it operated on. Now she is better. Mrs. Qui doesn't have any land. Hung, her second daughter, stopped going to the school. Her two youngest children are in grades 7 and 1. Hung and Mrs. Qui sell lottery tickets from door to door in the village.  Selling lottery tickets is important as it increases their income by $0.5/person/month. The average income is low at $7/person/month. Mrs. Qui repaid a first loan and now she wants to borrow a loan of $50 for her business.

loans.use: sell lottery tickets

loans.name: Huong

texts.en: Mrs. Huong and her husband are both 50 years old. They have 4 children between the ages of 21 and 15. Mrs. Huong has a cardiac disease and her second child is mentally retarded so both of them must spend about $20 for medical treatment per month. The family has a little land for cultivation: 4000 m2 to plant rice and cashew nut trees. The cashew nut trees are only two years old, so they don’t produce nuts yet. Thanh, her husband, works as a daily laborer, but the work is not stable. Her first child, Thanh, works as a day laborer at HCM city, but he only earns enough money for himself. Selling fish is very important for them to incease their income by $0.5/person/month. The average income is low at $8/person/month. Mrs. Huong has already repaid a loan of $50 and now she wants to borrow a loan of $75 for her rice planting and fish business.

loans.use: selling fish

loans.name: Manuel Jesús

texts.en:
Manuel is 38 years old, married and has two children, of 12 and 14 years of age. He used to be a carrier and, two years ago he had saved enough to initiate his own business. Now he is dedicated to the sale of clothes with the aid of his wife. Together they have been able to make considerable progress – the business has been growing and customers multiplied.

Now Manuel needs a loan of $475 dollars that he will use to purchase merchandise to be able to offer his clients a greater variety of products and secure their preference. He intends to pay back this loan in a lapse of 4 to 8 months. The well-being of this family and the growth of their business is in your hands.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Manuel tiene 38 años, es casado y tiene dos hijos, de 12 y 14 años de edad. Él tenía el oficio de cargador y con los ahorros que pudo acumular, hace dos años juntó el capital suficiente para iniciar su propio negocio, ahora se dedica a la venta de ropa, cuenta con la ayuda de su esposa para atener su negocio y juntos han podido sacarlo adelante, afortunadamente su tienda de ropa ha estado creciendo y sus clientes se han multiplicado.

Ahora Manuel necesita de un crédito por $ 475 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía para poder ofrecerle a sus clientes una mayor variedad y poder conservar su preferencia, el ofrece devolver este préstamo en un lapso de 4 a 8 meses. En tus manos está el bienestar de esta familia y el crecimiento de este negocio, no lo dude más y decídete a apoyarlos.

loans.use: Purchase Merchandise

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a single mother of three boys, 7, 14 and 16 years of age, and of an 18 year-old girl. She could not count on the support from the father of her children. Gloria is originally from Mérida, Yucatan and two years ago she obtained a position in the market of San Benito, where she sells seasonal fruit and vegetables. In order to set up shop, she used all the capital she had and now requires a loan of $ 475 dollars which she will use in the purchase of merchandise to be able to continue to expand her business. You can be an important part in the growth of this business and the life of this family if you decide to support Gloria

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Gloria es madre soltera de tres varones de 7, 14 y 16 años de edad, y de una mujer de 18 años, ella no contó con el apoyo del padre de sus hijos por lo que trabaja y se esfuerza día a día para sacarlos adelante ella sola. Gloria es originaria de Mérida, Yucatán, hace dos años pudo obtener un puesto en el mercado de San Benito, donde vende frutas y verduras de temporada.

Para acondicionar el local utilizó todo el capital que tenía, en estos momentos requiere de un préstamo pro la cantidad de $ 475 dólares, que utilizará en la compra de mercancía para poder continuar creciendo con su negocio. Tú puedes ser parte importante en el crecimiento de este negocio y en la vida de esta familia, decídete a apoyar a Gloria.

loans.use: Purchase Merchandise

loans.name: Agustín

texts.en:
Agustín is 51 years old, he is a driver and four years ago he started to sell tacos and cakes at weekends. Gradually he was gaining clients and the demand by its products was increasing. So he decided to dedicate himself full-time to his food business. He invested all his savings to buy a bigger stove and kitchen accessories.

At the moment Agustín requires a $700 loan to purchase ingredients to continue to produce the food he sells. He expects to pay it back in 6 to 12 months. He wants to grow his business and you can help him, your support will be very important to Agustín.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Agustín tiene 51 años de edad, él es chofer y desde hace cuatro años, los fines de semana atendía su negocio de venta de tacos y tortas, pero poco a poco fue ganando clientes y la demanda por sus productos se incrementó, así que optó por dedicarse toda la semana a la venta de comida, poco después necesitó comprar una estufa más grande y más accesorios de cocina, en lo que invirtió todos los ahorros que tenía.

En estos momentos Agustín requiere de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 700 dólares que utilizará en la compra de los ingredientes que necesita para continuar haciendo los alimentos que comercializa, ofrece devolverlos en un lapso de 6 a 12 meses. Él quiere hacer crecer su negocio y tú puedes ayudarlo, tu apoyo será de gran utilidad para Agustín, no lo dudes más.

loans.use: Purchase food ingredients

loans.name: José Gabriel

texts.en:
Mr. Jose Gabriel is 48 years old, from Mérida, Yucatan. He had a small electrical shop, but due to lack of work, for the last three years he has been dedicated to handcraft. He produces and sells plush dolls by catalogue. He is married and has six children, three girls 24, 20 and 18 years of age, and 3 boys of 22, 14 and 12 years-old. Maria Olga, his wife, helps in the business. Now the demand for their products has increased and they want to ensure the business continues to grow. At the moment, Jose needs a loan of $ 925 dollars that he will use to purchase of molds, fabrics, as well as other materials that they require to manufacture the dolls. He is committed to paying back the loan in 6 to 12 months. You can contribute to the growth of this business and to improve the quality of life of this family – make a decision to help them.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor José Gabriel tiene 48 años, es originario de Mérida, Yucatán. Tenía un pequeño taller eléctrico, pero por falta de trabajo, desde hace tres años se dedica a las manualidades, elabora y comercializa muñecos de peluche por medio de catálogo, él esta casado y tiene seis hijos, tres mujeres de 24, 20 y 18 años de edad, y 3 varones de 22, 14 y 12 años. Maria Olga, su esposa, también conoce de este oficio y le ayuda en el negocio. Ahora se ha incrementado la demanda por sus productos, ellos quieren que su negocio continúe creciendo.

En estos momentos, José necesita de un crédito por la cantidad de $ 925 dólares que empleará en la compra de moldes, de tela de peluche, así como otros materiales que requieren para la fabricación de los muñecos, él se compromete a devolver el préstamo en un lapso de 6 a 12 meses. Tú puedes contribuir al crecimiento de este negocio y a mejorar la calidad de vida de esta familia, no lo pienses más y decídete a ayudarlos.

loans.use: Purchase of materials

loans.name: Brígida Del Carmen

texts.en:
Mrs. Brígida del Carmen is 46 years old, married and has three children, two girls, 26 and 15 and an eight year-old boy. With the arrival of their son, family expenses increased and it was not possible to cover them with her husband’s income as a driver. Brígida, therefore, decided to start selling cosmetics. She invested all her savings in this venture and fortunately prospered.

Now Brígida needs a loan for $ 925 dollars that she will use to purchase merchandise to meet the increasing demand of its products and thus offer good service to her clientele. She is committed to paying back this amount in 6 to 12 months. You can play a key role in the growth of this business and in the life of this family. It is time to help those who need it most.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Brígida del Carmen tiene 46 años, es casada y tiene tres hijos, dos mujeres de 26 y 15 años y un varón de 8 años, con la llegada de su hijo menor, los gastos familiares se incrementaron y no era posible cubrirlos con el bajo ingreso de su esposo, que trabaja como chofer, por esta razón ella decidió iniciar con la venta de cosméticos, invirtió todos los ahorros que tenía y afortunadamente ha podido sacar adelante su negocio y su familia durante este tiempo.

Ahora Brígida necesita de un préstamo por $ 925 dólares que utilizará en la compra de mercancía para poder cubrir la creciente demanda por sus productos y así ofrecer un buen servicio a sus clientes, ella se compromete a devolver esta cantidad en un lapso de 6 a 12 meses. Tú puedes formar parte fundamental en el crecimiento de este negocio y en la vida de esta familia, hoy es tiempo de ayudar a quien más lo necesita.

loans.use: Compra de mercancía

loans.name: María Justina

texts.en:
Maria Justina is 49 years old, married and mother of three children of 13, 19 and 23 years of age. Her husband Jose works for the City Council of Mérida, where they were both born. Due to the need to help her husband with the their children's education, Maria began making clothes to relatives and friends. As she expanded her business, she began to buy and sell clothes also. Fortunately her business propered and continues to grow. Responsibility and hard work are characteristics that define Maria.

At the moment she needs a $700 loan to purchase clothes and offer her clients a greater variety and to maintain their preference. In your hands is the power to help this family improve their lives. Maria and her family thank for your generosity.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

La sra. Maria Justina tiene 49 años, es casada y madre de tres hijos de 13, 19 y 23 años de edad, su esposo José es empleado de el H. Ayuntamiento de Mérida, de donde ambos son originarios. Por la necesidad de ayudar a su esposo con los estudios de sus hijos, María empezó confeccionando ropa a sus familiares y conocidos y fue ampliando su negocio, ahora compra y venta de ropa nueva también, afortunadamente le ha ido muy bien y quiere que su negocio continúe creciendo.

Responsabilidad y trabajo son características que definen a María, en estos momentos ella necesita de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 700 dólares que empleará en la compra de ropa, para ofrecer a sus clientes una mayor variedad y conservar su preferencia. En tus manos está el poder ayudar a esta familia y mejorar sus condiciones de vida, decídete a apoyar a María, ella y su familia agradecen tu generosidad.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Isabel is from Mérida, Yucatan, has five children: four men of 28, 25, 21 and 18 years of age and one 24 year-old girl. The children are married and they help her with a small amount of money for expenses, but not enough to cover all her needs, so she decided to start her own business of selling shoes. Fortunately the money and hard work she invested in the business paid-off. In order to be able to fulfill her clients’ orders, Maria needs a loan of $700 dollars. She is committed to paying it back in 6 to 12 months. With your aid Maria can improve her life. She sincerely thanks you for your support and kindness. .

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria Isabel es originaria de Mérida, Yucatán, tiene cinco hijos, son cuatro hombres de 28, 25, 21 y 18 años de edad y una mujer de 24 años, sus hijos están casados y le ayudan con una pequeña cantidad de dinero para sus gastos, pero no le alcanzaba para cubrir todas sus necesidades, así que se decidió a iniciar su propio negocio con la venta de zapatos, afortunadamente el dinero que invirtió en el negocio ha rendido frutos y ha recibido un beneficio de su esfuerzo y trabajo.

Para poder surtir los pedidos que tiene de sus clientes Maria necesita de un préstamo por $ 700 dólares que empleará con este fin, ella se compromete a devolver esta cantidad en un lapso de 6 a 12 meses. Con tu ayuda puedes ayudarla a mejorar sus condiciones de vida, apóyala a seguir adelante con su negocio, ella agradece sinceramente tu ayuda y cariño.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Nielzer Laureano

texts.en:
Ten years ago, Mr. Nielzer started out as an assistant in a watch shop. After learning the trade, and with the savings he had been able to accumulate, he started his own small business in the market at Mérida, where he works selling and repairing watches. He is married and has eight children, who are the reason he works arduously day after day to get ahead. He wants to offer his children a better quality of life and he wants them to be able to finish their schooling.

Nielzer wants to continue growing his business, and for this he needs a loan of $375.00, which he will use for the purchase of watches, watch parts, and batteries. These are the items he needs most in order to continue offering the best quality service to his clients. He promises to repay this amount over a period of 5 to 10 months. Nielzer trusts in people who help those who need it most, and he sincerely thanks you for any help you can offer him.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Dulce María

texts.en:
Dulce María is 43 years old, married, with two daughters ages 9 and 14. Her husband works in a laboratory, and in order to obtain some extra income and help out with the household expenses, 10 years ago she started selling jewelry. At first she sold it to her neighbors and relatives, and by means of their recommendations she has become more well-known and the demand for her products has increased.

Thanks to Dulce's effort and hard work, her business has grown, but now she needs a loan of $375.00, which will allow her to buy merchandise to cover the demand of her customers. She offers to repay this amount over a period of 6 to 12 months. You can help make Dulce's dreams a reality. She sincerely thanks you for your generosity and support.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Maria De Jesús

texts.en:
María de Jesús is a widow with three children, all of whom are married. She started her business four years ago, when she became a widow and needed a source of income to support herself. She decided to start selling footwear and handbags for ladies. The business has gone very well and it is growing. With her business, María de Jesús has been able to have a better quality of life and to move forward as a single person.

In order to continue the growth of her business, she is requesting a loan of $925.00, which she will use to buy merchandise and in that way diversify her product line and increase her sales. She will repay this loan over a period of to 12 months. María awaits your collaboration and support in order to continue the growth she has already achieved.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Maria De Guadalupe

texts.en:
María is married and has 2 sons. Her husband is employed, yet the money he makes is not enough to make ends meet because their children are growing up causing the household expenses to increase. This is why María decided to open a business so she could her husband with the income and give her sons a better quality of life. She started her business in 1995 and little by little it has been improving. By 1998 María already had a middle sized loyal group of clientele, which was very satisfying for her and encouraged her to continue working. María is a hard working woman. ,p> María needs a $750 loan to buy merchandise to provide a greater variety of products, and keep pace with the demand of her clients, which are mainly women. She will repay the loan within 6 to 12 months and she is thankful for your support.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

María está casada y tiene dos hijos, su esposo trabaja como empleado y ella al estar creciendo los hijos, sus gastos también, por ello se vio en la necesidad de hacer algo para obtener un ingreso extra al de su esposo y poder brindarles a sus hijos una mejor calidad de vida. Empezó con su negocio en 1995 y poco a poco ha ido mejorando y ya para el año 1998 tenía una cartera de clientes fija y de tamaño medio, esto la llena de satisfacción y le da ganas de seguir adelante, María es una mujer muy trabajadora.

Está solicitando un préstamo por la cantidad de US $ 750 para comprar mercancía para su negocio y así tener un mejor inventario y poder satisfacer las necesidades y pedidos de sus clientes, que en su mayoría son mujeres. Este préstamo lo pagará en un lapso de 6 a 12 meses y les agradece su apoyo.

loans.use: Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Hat

texts.en: Mr. Hat is 71 years old. His wife is 60. They don't have any land for cultivation and they are elderly so they can’t work as day-laborers. One way for them to earn a living is to sell foods. For this business, and to expand they need a loan of US $70.

loans.use: To sell foods

loans.name: Dung

texts.en: Mrs. Dung is 33 years old and her husband is 35 years old. They have 3 children. The oldest child is 13 years old and the youngest is 2 years old. They don’t have any land for cultivation. Her husband is a day-laborer, but his work is unstable. Mrs. Dung has a small business selling foods from her home. They live in difficulty. This family needs US $70 to expand their business and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To sell foods

loans.name: Loan

texts.en: Mrs. Loan is 37 years old. Her husband died a long time ago. She has 2 children. One of them is 15 years old and the other is 12. They are both students.  She doesn’t have any land for cultivation, so she has to trade banana leaves. Everyday she buys the leaves around her village and sells them in the city, which is far from her village - about 100km. It is very difficult for her to do this job, but she has no choice. She needs US $70 to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy and sell banana leaves

loans.name: Bay

texts.en: Mr. Bay is 59 years old, and his wife is 52 years old. They have 5 children. The oldest child is 22, and he is a worker. The second child is 20. The three others are 17, 15, and 12 years old, and are students. He doesn’t have any land for cultivation. His wife and their second child have a small business at the market trading fruits. To manage and expand this business, they need US $50.

loans.use: To trade fruits at the market

loans.name: Quan

texts.en: Mrs. Quan is 85 years old. Now, she lives with 2 family members; her niece and nephew. They are 19 and 17 years old. She doesn’t have any land for cultivation. The main income of the family is to trade betel and areca. She needs US $50 for this small business.

loans.use: to trade betels and arecas

loans.name: Chut

texts.en: Mr. Chut is 52 years old. He is a stevedore. His wife's name is Huong, and she is 53 years old. She sells foods at the market. They have two children.
